head_text.subj: INT. SUBWAY TRAIN- VERY EARLY MORNING

text: CLOSE on SIMON JAMES. His eyes are closed. It is difficul to tell whether he is asleep or not. We hear a voice off screen.
You're in my place. SIMON opens his eyes. He looks up.
Sorry?

You're in my place. SIMON looks around the carriage. It is almost completely EMPTY. He looks back at the MAN quizzically. The MAN stares at SIMON in a hostile manner. Perplexed, SIMON gets up and stands by a hand rail. The M takes SIMON’S place, folds,out a newspaper and starts to read. SIMON looks at the MAN who, from behind his paper, raises his middle finger at SIMON. SIMON looks at his reflection in the glass window of the SUBWAY train. He looks ghostly and half-formed. SIMON is in his late-twenties to mid-thirties. He is of average height and build. His hair color and clothing are unremarkable. Although he is handsome, he is not overly s In“short, “he is a thoroughly average man. The title appears over Simon’s face, so forlorn it almost makes you want to cry. “THE DOUBLE.” The train stops and the door opens. A crowd of people spills in, pushing Simon back. He fight against the flow to try to get out. Several people bump directly into Simon without so much as a word of apology.

(being pushed) Sorry. Simon waits for the others to get on the train. His path finally clear, he attempts to leave again. As he steps forward one last person jumps onto the train bumping him to the side.

Excuse me. The person doesn’t even acknowledge Simon. There is a beep and Simon has to leap forward, barely making it out through the sliding doors. As the train departs, we see SIMON getting smaller and smaller on the EMPTY PLATFORM.

We are in New York, or some comparable metropolis. Though everything is familiar the world is somewhat off, somewha strange. Simon walks down a MOSTLY EMPTY street, keeping his eyes lowered. There are huge buildings on either side of him. Any other people on the street are walking in the other direction and Simon has to dodge them to avoid collisions

SIMON waits outside AN ENORMOUS OFFICE, BUILDING. It’s relatively deserted. TIME PASSES and a few people, come and go. Eventually, SIMON spots. a woman, HANNAH, approaching the LOBBY of the building. SIMON smiles, then composes himsel and skips after. her.
Simon enters the lobby of the office building. A few step ahead we see HANNAH. She is using a card to swipe through barrier. Hannah is Simon’s age. She is a little unkempt, but very pretty.

Hannah, are you going to... Simon smiles and quickens his pace a bit. He takes out hi card, and swipes through, but the barrier doesn’t move. A GUARD sitting behind a large marble desk calls out to Simon just as Hannah begins to turn around.
You, hey. Simon turns and looks at the guard, surprised to be singl out. He looks a little nervous.
Me?
All visitors have to sign in. Simon moves to the desk where he takes a pen.
My card’s not working for some reason.
All visitors have to sign in.

I work here. I have a card. My name is Simon James - you don’t recognise me? He sees Hannah getting into an elevator and watches=the door close. Simon frowns and signs the sheet. His is the first name. He is given a DAY PASS that says ‘SIMON AMES - TEMPORARY VISITOR’. SIMON .(CONT’D) Oh, sorry. My name is Simon James. Not Simon,Ames... Simon trails off as he sees that the guard is no longer paying attention to him. INT. ELEVATOR — EARLY MORNING Simon rides up an enormous elevator. The biggest elevator you have ever seen. We watch Simon from above as he STANDS ALONE in the middl

Simon sits at his cubicle in the middle of an enormous office space. The place is separated into hundreds of cubicles. SIMON is the first person there. His desk and cubicle are just slightly too small for him. Every cubicle has the same computer. The computers are enormous, taking up half of the cubicle space. They are box-y and make loud whirring noises that fi11 the office. The office has no windows other than wall made of tinted glass.  4. Simon sits down at his desk, adjusting himself in his too small chair. He looks at a stack of paper and frowns a little. A few people enter the office dressed as Simon is, with a white shirt and tie. Simon looks up and greets them with his slight, hesitant voice, but none of them acknowledge him.

All the cubicles are now full with office workers. Everyo is much, much older than Simon. Simon sits at his desk, copying a hand-written page onto his computer. The pages are all questionnaires: long survey-like documents of various people, filled with categories like ‘profession", ‘marital status’, ‘personal habits’, ‘interests’ etc Simon finishes up the page he is copying and moves,to the next page. He has nearly completed copying an, enormous batch.

Simon stares off into the distance. He occasionally pecks something out on his keyboard. Across the room we see MR. PAPADOPOULOS, an extraordinari round man. He has thick eyebrows and his brown suit indicates that he is in management.

That’s right, that’s great. Making the big push! Simon jumps up and approaches Mr. Papadopoulos. He fixes his hair and grabs the stack of papers he has just completed “copying. Papadopoulos talks to everyone and no one at all as he weaves his way through the maze of cubicles. PAPADOPOULOS (CONT’D) Excellent work everyone. We've got to work double-time now, making the big push. We watch from above as Simon, carrying his stack of paper triangulates his way through the cubicles to cut off Mr. Papadopoulos.
Excuse me. Umm, Mr. Papadopoulos?
Yes, what’s that?
I wanted to tell you I finished up. I’ve done the first...
Excellent job! (he takes the stack of paper from Simon) That's the type of initiative we need. I’1l tell the colonel right away. How long have you been here, son? Just started, eh?
(frowning) Seven years, sir.
Ah, of course. (slaps his head with realization) Thank you.

(confused) You're welcome, sir. (beat) Actually, I have some rather exciting ideas I‘4ve been wanting to share with the colonel about what we could do with the computers, things that would make the reports much more powerful, and efficient and...

Very interesting, I must say. (pauses ) Come with me. Simon follows Papadopoulos. He seems a bit startled and excited, he might get his chance to discuss his ideas. PAPADOPOULOS (CONT’D) My daughter’s name is Melanie.
(confused) A nice name. Papadopoulos has now stopped at a strange office behind t tinted glass. The door says, “The Colonel’s Quarters. Executive Offices.”

She's interning for the holidays.  6. MELANIE is sixteen years old. She smacks her gum, has her foot up on the desk and is painting her toenails. PAPADOPOULOS (CONT’D) Say hello, Melanie. Melanie doesn’t even look at Simon.
Hey.
(confused) Hello.
Stanley here’s going to be your mentor. Simon nods along happily for a moment, then looks at Papadopoulos.
What?
An hour a day... at your discretion. (beat, quietly to Simon) She's a good girl, but no head for figures. With that Papadopoulos enters the strange office.
Idiot. (to SIMON) You can go now. Simon remains, looking confused.
Yes, I do have to be going, I suppose.
Because if I were to find out how depressingly meaningless what you do actually is I might be forced to feel sorry for you.
Simon searches his wallet for a dollar. He can only find five. He uses the change machine and picks up the heavy load of quarters.

Simon sips his coffee and stares blankly ahead. He sees a POSTER on the notice board that says, ‘THE COLONEL’S BALL. DRINKS, DANCING, ENJOYMENT. ATTENDANCE MANDATORY. ’ Harris enters the room. He looks through his wallet for a moment before turning to talk to Simon.
You finished your report yet?
Just a little while ago.
You think you could help me out on mine?
I did the entire thing last time.
I know. I still have the inspiration, it’s just my powers of concentration seem to have waned.
(shaking, head) Just leave it on my desk. I’1l get to it.
Do you have any money? SIMON sighs and gives HARRIS some coins for the machine. makes a coffee.
(smiling) Fantastic. (hesitates, not much to say) Uh, what else is going on? SIMON SHRUGS.
You going to the Colonel’s Ball?
It’s mandatory.
Some drunk girl’s gonna get it.  There’s a pause.
See ya.

SIMON stands with a large stack of paper under his arm. INT. PHOTOCOPYING DEPT. SIMON waits at the counter. He sees HANNAH approach. Hannah's face is hard to read and she doesn’t give out to many visual clues. She’s different than the rest of Simon coworkers, but inscrutable.
Hi. Can I get these copied please?
(not unkindly) I did these for you yesterday, didn’t I?
Well, it was something... A TELEPHONE RINGS. HANNAH steps away to answer.
Sorry. A MEAN-LOOKING woman, LIZ, TAKES her place.
Why didn’t you just print out two copies?
Sorry...
You shouldn’t use this department for just one copy. She takes the papers.
This is the last time. SIMON watches HANNAH talk on the phone as we hear the rumble of PHOTOCOPIERS.
Hey, Hannah. Can you stay late? I’ve got to get this lump checked out. HANNAH looks over and nods.

Simon sits alone at a circular table in the middle of an enormous cafeteria. People sit together at tables all around him, while Simon barely touches his food and reads a book. Simon looks up from the book and sees Hannah also sitting alone at a nearby table. HARRIS sidles up beside him.
You hit it yet?
What?
That chick, Hannah, you banged her yet?
I'm just trying...
That’s the spirit!
(frowning) No! I’ve barely talked to her...
Make a move at the Colonel’s Ball. Those things end up like Roman orgies.
She doesn’t strike me as the type to go.
It’s mandatory. Everyone has to go.
Not everyone goes.  10.
She's pretty good looking, but as long as you don’t talk much and she’s wasted... They sit in silence for a moment.
Hey, I just realised: ‘Colonel's Ball’ sounds funny.
Simon sits at his desk. He looks very tired. He is talkin on the phone.
(into phone) Yes, mother. I’ll be there. I’m just working a bit late. THE OFFICE is empty. HARRIS enters.
(into phone) Goodbye, then.
See ya.
Bye.
Hey - watch this. HARRIS climbs up onto one of the desks and manages to jum across all the cubicles till he’s by the door on the othe side of the room. He bows and leaves.
Simon stands across the street from his office building, not many people are around. Hannah exits the building alone. Simon slinks back into t shadows and watches her go. He sighs.

Simon sits in an uncomfortable looking chair, opposite hi MOTHER. Simon’s Mother is not particularly old, but she has cloud eyes and a generally vacant expression. In the distance we see other residents watching a dated game show. All the furniture seems a bit strange.  11. Closer is a tiny old lady of unclear ethnicity, perhaps a GYPSY WOMAN. She is bundled up and seems to be staring at Simon. Simon glances at her occasionally, looking uncomfortable.

Things are going very well for me at work, you'll be happy to know. I expect to speak with The Colonel about some plans I’ve been working on. You wouldn’t believe what these computers are capable of. I really think they’re going to change things.
(a bit angry) What are you going on about? Simon continues as though he’s used to this.
There’s also a girl that I’m interested in, and well, it’s been going slowly, but I think something might be about to happen.
Your mother says you are a strange boy.
Srange? No. Well, she’s never been particularly warm, and sometimes she gets confused.
(forceful) You'll never catch a female using that puny worm as bait. Simon’s mother reaches for his lap but he uncomfortably pushes her hand away.
Though she does have her moments of lucidity.
Let me see your hand.
No, thanks I’m fine.
You're not right.  12. Simon looks a little concerned, but a man from the STAFF approaches him.
May I speak with you?
Yes. (to Gypsy) Excuse me. Simon walks a few steps away to speak with the man.
There seems to be a discrepancy in your bill.
Yes, well, there was a rather large cost increase, and no explanation, so I thought it might be a mistake.
There’s a new price.
And why is that?
Improvements. Simon looks around at the obviously unchanged room.
But that seems a little...
Would you like your mother to rot on the street?
(thinks a second) No.
Good. That’s settled. Simon seems about to say something, but shakes his head.
She doesn’t seem quite as well.
(already hurrying away ) It’s because she’s old.  13. Simon sighs and looks back at his mother. The gypsy woman stares at him.
Simon walks home through an enormous complex of tall apartment buildings. They look so alike you can’t tell th difference between any of them.

Simon sifts through the dumpster behind an apartment building. Above is a shoot from which the trash comes. A black bag drops down as Simon looks through the debris. Simon has several scraps of paper in his hand but is stil searching. He finally finds another scrap of paper and greedily grab it. He steps down from the dumpster and is embarrassed to see JANITOR watching him.
You shouldn’t be doing that. SIMON. Sorry.
Simon hurries across the courtyard to the apartment directly across from the building the dumpster was attach to.

SIMON hurries up the stairs, almost running into an old woman on his way up. INT. SIMON’S APARTMENT. Simon enters his apartment and quickly walks to the windo turning on a small floor lamp. His apartment is very sparse and small; a bookshelf, desk and a small television. There are few pictures on the wal and his bed sits on the floor. It is meticulously clean, the product of a very ordered personality. Simon looks out the window to the hundreds of apartments the building across from him. Simon reaches up and lifts the window open as wide as it can go. The wind pours through the apartment and Simon leans out, looking into the great distance below.  14. He takes his jacket off and looks into a rather large telescope. It is trained on the apartment opposite his. Hannah stands at a drafting table where she see draws a face. Her apartment is colorful and cozy, but there is something of the same feeling of loneliness in her room a well. She is concentrated fully, biting her lip. She looks charming. She steps back from the drawing and we see it i Liz; the mean person she works with. It is very well done She is unhappy with the drawing, though, and tears it up, tossing it down the trash chute. On her wall are a handful of completed drawings, presumab of other faces from the office. Hannah has let her hair down. She looks very comfortable and walks to the window where she languidly stretches. We see a hint of her bare midriff. She then walks to her couch and lays back, yawning deeply In his apartment Simon reaches for a simple chair and remains watching Hannah. Simon takes the pieces of paper he collected from the tra and puts them on the floor,;,.working to piece them toget We see that it is another of Hannah’s drawings, an earlie draft of LIZ - but still very accomplished. Simon looks up from the floor and returns to the telescop He sees his reflection in the glass, hollow and ghostly.

What’s wrong with you? HANNAH gets up and leaves the room. SIMON waits for a whi before allowing himself to tilt the telescope and survey Aeman watching a commercial. A beautiful woman brushing her hair in the mirror. Someone with his back to us peeing in the bathroom. Simon moves the telescope to the apartment above Hannah's and we see a MAN dressed very formally in a tuxedo starin directly at Simon with his own pair of binoculars. The ma has a piece of paper pinned to his lapel. He is holding a bloody handkerchief to the side of his head. Simon takes a step back in shock and embarrassment before looking through the telescope again. The man is still there, staring at Simon through his binoculars. The man waves at Simon.  15. He looks exactly the same as the man who told Simon out of his place n the Subway. Simon hesitantly raises his hand in reply. The man steps on the ledge of his window. The man, now steadied on the window, again waves at The man dramatically leaps from the window. The man to fall and fall. We never see him land. Simon gasps and jumps up. He still has his hand up response to the man.

The flashing of police lights fills the courtyard. voices in the background. to move Simon. seems in We hear Simon leans against the side of the building, within the area cordoned off by the police. Two police officers are carefully carrying a body, alread enclosed within a bag, dowm.a ladder. The body had on a hard veranda. landed A FAT DETECTIVE.is Sipping on a cup of coffee and writing notes as he talks to Simon. A FEMALE DETECTIVE looks over his shoulders as he writes.
And then what did you do?
I called the police.
Right. (beat) Anything else?
He waved at me.
(seeming momentarily interested) Yeah?
Right before he jumped. He waved.  16.
How'd he wave? Simon makes a waving motion, looks embarrassed.
Did you wave back? Simon doesn’t say anything for a moment.
I wonder why he did it?
His note said he was lonely. Should of got a dog.
Or exercised more. That’s important.
Should I write that down?
Maybe, in parenthesis. Simon shakes his head.
Did he suffer?
Splat. Simon grimaces. Two paramedics are loading preparing to load the body into an ambulance.
Do you see this sort of thing often?
Every day. That’s what we do, suicides.
Only suicides?
Yep.
For the whole city? The detective looks at him like he’s crazy  17.

We can barely cover the neighborhood. (beat) You know, the funny thing is he would have landed on the awning if he’d just jumped a few feet to the right. Probably survived if we'd gotten here quick enough. Horribly maimed of course, but still.
If you can get them to the hospital quickly enough to stop the brain swelling.

That’s true. We see Hannah a few feet away. Her hair is down and»wshe hastily dressed. The detectives walks off to check on something and Simon watches them. Simon walks up to Hannah. SIMON. Hannah? HANNAH looks at.Simon, somewhat dazed.
It’s Simon. I work in the same office as you. I often photocopy things...
What are you doing here?
The man that jumped. I was the one who saw him.
How?
I live in that building.
He lived above me. My neighbor told me about it. (beat) I didn’t know him.  18.
He waved at me.
(shaking her head) Strange. As they watch the police work with moving the body. Hanna cringes and grabs Simon by the arm. Simon talks loud, as though he is resolved.
It’s the Colonel’s Ball tomorrow. (beat) Do you think you'll go?
It’s mandatory. They stand in silence for a moment. HANNAH turns to leave Simon shouts after her.
Hannah.
Yes? SIMON. It’s terrible to,be alone too much.
Simon and Hannah sit opposite one another in the booth of an ancient looking diner.

Yes. So, I’ve been working on a thing to do with regression analysis. Like, in my spare time. I’m pretty happy with it. I’m hoping to show it to the Colonel when it’s ready. I mean, you wouldn’t believe what these computers are capable of. I really think they’re going to change things.

(neutral) I don’t really understand computers. They are quiet and a WAITRESS comes and drops off their drinks.  19. Hannah has tea in front of her while Simon has some blue soda. Simon looks a little confused.
(Calling after the waitress) Erm, I ordered orange juice... No reply.

But I suppose this is just as good. They sit quietly for a few moments. Hannah and Simon turn to a nearby television which is playing an odd futuristic sci-fi/noir movie. Simon looks down at the table. Hannah’s wrist is near his hand. It is fine and fragile, her hand is stained with pencil smudges. He slowly moves his hand forward. Hannah turns to look at Simon and he quickly averts his eyes back to the television show.
(on the TV, dramatic) There’s no such thing as... second chances.
I like this show. Hannah smiles at Simon. He finds it hard to read her expression. They return back to the screen for a moment.
Do you draw?
(looking suspicious) Why?
It’s just your hand. Hannah looks down and rubs the pencil marks from her hand We hear a PHONE in the background.
It’s from the printer.
Because it’s cool if you do, I like...
You've got a call.  20.
It’s not for me.
Frumpy looking guy named Simon.
(hesitates) That’s me. (to Hannah) Hold on.
Simon quickly grabs for the pay phone. He tries to look around the corridor into the restaurant but just barely can’t see where Hannah is sitting.

(into phone) Mom? (beat) Yes, but it’s just a night terror. (beat) No that didn’t ever happen. (beat) I know I’m a disappointment. (beat) I have to go, I’m with a girl. (beat) Yes, a female girl. (beat, sighs) I don’t know if she’s fertile.

Simon stands at the table, but Hannah is now gone. Her te is-only partially finished. He picks up a note, it reads, “Sorry, had to go. Maybe se you at the Colonel’s ball - Hannah.” Simon looks both discouraged and excited. He lifts his ey once again to the silly show on the television. It goes t a commercial break and we cut to an image of an enormous pile of papers, taller than a man.

Think of what your business could do if it had a giant, electronic brain. The stack explodes and the sheets of paper begin to fall, tumbling one after another to reveal an enormous computer A MAN is under it, typing away, smoking a cigar  21. This is THE COLONEL, a European-looking MAN in his 60s/70 dressed like a member of the British Royal Family. VOICE OVER (CONT’D) Well now it has. Meet the Colonel. The Colonel walks through an enormous room of attractive women clacking away at computers. VOICE OVER (CONT’D) For years, the Colonel has provided your business with the most detailed personal profiling on the market. Using his powerful super computers to provide all the information you need to know exactly who your target consumer is.
We reveal that Simon, Melanie and Harris*watch an ORIENTATION VIDEO.
(whisper) Did she say anything else?
(whisper) No. Just,that she was definitely going.
You should have stroked her earlobe.
This is colossally boring. Simon and Harris return their attention to the video.

The Colonel will go to any lengths to find everything about anybody. We see a montage of data collection. In each shot, The Colonel is Co-ordinating. Men in overcoats conducting bubble tests: taking notes at what someone buys at a drugstore; looking through someone’s trash.
It’s actually quite exciting, the new technology is incredibly powerful. Right now we’re using a scattershot approach, but... (MORE )

I’ve been meaning to talk to your father and the Colonel about this... using simple regression analysis and honing in on a few key signals we can use these machines to find out anything we need incredibly quickly. We could really reconfigure the entire business. (beat) You know, I really think computers are going to change things. Both Melanie and Harris look at Simon as though he’s craz We return to the video. THE COLONEL is shaking hands with various people next to one of his enormous computers
Governments, corporations, foreign nationals... The Colonel can service all your needs.
Are you touching my earlobe? We return to see Harris, reaching his hand behind Simon's head, limply holding Melanie’s earlobe.
Yes; I am.
Harris: that’s not appropriate.
I’m going to leave now. (beat, to Simon) And, you're pathetic. She’s got to be at the ball, it’s mandatory.
Does that mean you’ll be there?
I’m underage, you sack of shit.
Don’t fight it. She gets up and leaves.  23.
(to SIMON) I just hope I’m not so upset that I tell my Dad about this.
(turning to HARRIS) What are you doing? You shouldn't even be here. He leaves. We see the projection screen.
Because The Colonel knows there are no special people
(straight to camera, with a slight Russian accent) Just people.
SIMON stuffs his work clothes into a bag. He is wearing a tuxedo. He looks in the mirror and practices introduction

Oh - hi Hannah.,Hannah! Hi. Hannah? Hey. Simon. From the scene of the suicide! Etc. INT. OFFICE —, EVENING Again, Simon is the last one there. He dumps his bag underneath his desk. He looks around tentatively, then steps up onto his desk to repeat the trick Harris did. Bu as soon as he sets foot on another desk an alarm sounds. He looks around in panic.
Simon sits opposite someone who is typing up a report on him.
What are you writing?
Don’t make this worse for yourself.
I’ve never done anything like that before.  24.
Card please. SIMON hands over his identity card. The PERSON puts it in a card reader and keys something in.
This card's corrupted. You'll get a replacement in six to eight weeks. INVESTIGATOR ONE cuts it up.
How will I get in and out of the building?

The card replacement fee will be deducted from your wages. INT. LOBBY OF COLONEL’S BALL VENUE - EVENING A large door, like that of an AMBASSADORIAL BUILDING. Simon stands in the lobby, next to a MAN with a clipboard Behind him a WOMAN is looking something up on a computer. Simon has clearly been waiting a long time. GUESTS in evening wear arrive and enter the building. We hear a band play in the background.
Why does no one else need to swipe in?

We carry out these checks at random. If you’re suggesting you're being persecuted, you’1l need to fill out this form. He hands Simon a form which is headed ‘YOU HAVE THE RIGHT NOT TO BE PERSECUTED’. HARRIS appears.
See you in there.
See? He knows I work here. Harris! Tell him who I am.
I’ve never seen that man before in my life! And he disappears.  25.
He’s being a dick... The man looks sternly at Simon for swearing.
-a silly person. I had my card confiscated-
Because it was corrupted.
(calling out) I can’t find him on the list!
She can’t find you on the list.
Everyone is on the list. I’ve worked here for seven years.
Please step away.
I work here. Why would I try to break in to something that’s mandatory? It’s a job requirement.
Are you planning to use force?
Do you know what mandatory means? No one wants to go to this. We hear joyous cheers from within.

Please step away. EXT. COLONEL’S BALL VENUE - MOMENTS LATER Simon wanders around in disbelief. He tries to see what’s going on inside, but the angle is too steep. EXT. SERVICE ENTRANCE COLONEL’S BALL VENUE - MOMENTS LATE Simon creeps in through the kitchens. A couple of staff members look at him suspiciously. Simon stops and looks around and pretends that he’s inspecting the premises.  26.
Very good. Excellent. I’1l be telling the Colonel about the great work you're all doing.

SIMON, crouched down peers through a crack in the door. W see his POV of a grand ballroom. People are milling about eating canapes, chatting, laughing and dancing to the mus played by a band. The band are impossibly old. A WAITER swooshes by, leaving SIMON exposed in an odd posture. He walks forward in a crouched manner and tries to casually segue into standing up and walking properly. A few people notice him, but he’s largely ignored.

SIMON picks up a drink and some hors d’oeuvres. He looks a long table full of strange raffle prizes. The band play a fanfare and people shuffle «to attention. Mr. Papadapolous takes to the stage and stands on a pre- prepared box.

And now we take a brief break in our revelry to honour our Young Employee of the,Year. And to present the award is» last year’s winner, Mr. Stevens. Fanfare. Mr Steven’s approaches: he looks between fifty a sixty. PAPADOPOLOUS gets down off the box and picks it up

And the winner is... He ‘produces an envelope from his pocket. Papadapolous co over to help him, as Mr. Stevens has a prosthetic hand an finds it difficult to open it. The band’s drum roll start to» become frighteningly long. MR. STEVENS (CONT’D) Mr. Harris. We he hear a whoop of delight from HARRIS - a spotlight finds him. We have audience applause. We see Simon, unable to believe his eyes.

Simon wanders through a series of rooms, looking for Hannah.  27. Various people enjoying themselves. Papadopolous is doing vaguely racist impression of someone, to the delight of some business colleagues. He sees Hannah sitting at the other end of a room. She’s a fifties-style ball gown and is smoking a cigarette. Sim watches her for a while. She looks a bit bored, alone, seemingly ready for someone to approach her. Time seems to stand still. The song played by the band sounds epic and romantic. Just as she looks up and returns his gaze, two men grab Simon and start dragging him out of the building.
You're not meant to be here.

What do you mean? I work here. SIMON looks mortified. He gazes at Hannah, «who looks confused, but not particularly concerneds)More and more people at the dance start looking around. The band stops playing.
You’re making a mistake. I work here. I work here! He tries to shrug them off.

There’s no need to drag me. They simply re-double their aggression - the struggle becomes; more undignified. A few steps away we see The Colonel. He listens to someon speaking, nodding with a benign, patrician air. He turns look at Simon. Someone whispers in the Colonel’s ear. Sim looks up: this is the first time he has seen this figure the flesh. EXT. COLONEL’S BALL VENUE SIMON is thrown down the steps and onto the street.

The appropriate amendments will be made to your record. Simon gets up. He is visibly shaken. Behind the doors we can just make out the sound of the band and see some movement in the hall. Simon staggers about for a bit. He is frustrated, pacing back and forth, seeming almost like he’s going to cry.  28. Simon starts to punch at the air and flail. Completely letting go.

What’s wrong with them? I’ma person, like other people. What’s wrong with you?! It gives the Colonel the complete wrong idea about me. I have things to say to him. Ideas that he’d very much like to hear, I’m sure. Simon pushes the glass door several times causing it to clatter as he continues to yell. Finally he kicks the door which gives a shiver, but the only real result is a sharp pain in his foot. Simon begins to curse to himself loudly. The door swings open and the security man again looks sternly at Simon who continues to curse.
Did you want something? Simon looks as though he’s about to say something, really let the man have it, but as he clutches his foot he finds himself saying
